The thought crossed Sonia's mind that he might be crazy, but she quickly pushed it away. "No, it's something else," she thought, unable to understand it.

“Listen, Sonia,” he said suddenly and firmly, “if I had just killed because I was hungry,” he emphasized each word and looked at her seriously, “I would be happy now. You must believe that! What would it matter to you,” he said in despair, “if I confessed I did something wrong? What do you get from feeling like you’ve won over me? Ah, Sonia, is that why I came to you today?”

Sonia tried to say something but stayed silent.

“I asked you to come with me yesterday because you are all I have left.”

“Go where?” Sonia asked quietly.

“Not to steal or murder, don’t worry,” he said with a bitter smile. “We are very different… And you know, Sonia, it’s only now that I realize where I wanted you to go with me yesterday! When I said it, I didn’t know. I wanted one thing: for you not to leave me. You won’t leave me, Sonia?”

She held his hand tightly.

“Why did I tell her? Why did I let her know?” he cried in despair, looking at her with deep sadness. “You’re waiting for an explanation from me, Sonia; I can see that.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov expresses his inner turmoil and desperation for connection with Sonia amidst his guilt and moral conflict.
